ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: A lot of reading texts andlearning new words. Not as much grammar. Basically what you'd expect for a middle-level language class. If you like the language, keep taking it. Mashad does a good job.

With world politics as they are today, Persian is such a useful language to learn. And honestly it's easy. There are only really 4 levels so unlike other languages, you can master it in 2 years. There's tons of overlap with French and English and the grammar is simple and regular.There's a lot of change going on in the department right now and it's not clear who will be teaching next year. And with a language, the professor is everything. So I suggest shopping it and seeing what you think of whoever ends up teaching.

Persian 130 consisted of a great deal of readings, conversations, and writing exercises. For my purposes, this was very useful as I am trying to improve on my written Persian and vocabulary and was able to do so in this class. I think its essential to continue with L3 Persian if one hopes to get even close to fluency and would therefore recommend this class, especially with Professor Mohit.
